div.head: Indiana Historical Society
div.p: The Indiana Historical Society has completed for its William Henry Smith Memorial Library, which is to have a room in the new State Library and Historical Building, a portfolio measuring approximately 30 by 27 inches, containing measured drawings, blueprints, detailed studies, and photographs of the former Indiana School for the Blind, which stood on the square bounded by Meridian, St. Clair, Pennsylvania , and North Streets, Indianapolis . This material would enable an architectural sculptor to make an exact miniature of the building, and it would be possible to rebuild the structure (removed in 1930-31, to permit the grading of the World War Memorial Plaza) from the drawings and pictures.

It is the hope of the Society to get similar records of all public buildings of importance in the state which are in danger of being torn down in the near future. The architecture of a country or state is one of the most important evidences of its culture, and is an important contribution, as well, to the education of its citizens. Moreover, the restoration of buildings is now being carried on to such an extent that drawings, details, and models of notable period buildings are certain to be needed in the future. If such information had been at hand in the case of "Wakefield," the birthplace of George Washington , thousands of dollars would have been saved in its rebuilding for the Washington Bicentennial, and one would have far more confidence that the building is accurately reproduced.

The projects for the restoration of Williamsburg, Virginia , Spring Mill, Indiana, and
Salem, Illinois , afford other illustrations of similar needs. Members of the Historical Society will be doing a service by calling attention to important typical or period buildings anywhere in the state which are in imminent danger of destruction.

The Society is joining this summer in the archaeological survey of the Whitewater Valley. Glenn A. Black, of Indianapolis , long an amateur archaeologist and fresh from a year's work with the Ohio State Archaeological and Historical Society,
is field director. A number of individuals are co-operating. It is hoped that the Historical Bureau will be able to aid also.

This work is apparently better understood and appreciated outside of the state than within it. Leading archaeologists in Michigan, Illinois, Ohio , and the East, are looking to it for light upon questions raised by the archaeological work carried on in other states. Until the Society and other organizations made their small beginning in this field six years ago, Indiana was one of the most backward states in the Union as far as concerned a scientific study of its prehistoric inhabitants. The public generally in this state has not yet awakened to the interest and importance of this study.

In the United States at large there has been a veritable archaeological "drive". Some of the ablest men in the country have devoted themselves to solving the many riddles of our prehistory. In Mexico, Central America, and Peru, prehistoric cultures have been unearthed which are nothing less than startling. The present civilization in these countries is now looked upon, in part, as an outgrowth of prehistoric cultures, as well as of European colonization. Yields in the United States have not been quite so significant but have been sufficient to enable scientists to formulate reasonable working hypotheses concerning our prehistory. The importance of a scientific study of mounds, now being rapidly destroyed by pot-hunters, as well as by cultivation, roadbuilding and natural forces, can hardly be overemphasized. The Historical Division of the Carnegie Institute of Washington has turned all its resources into the channel of archaeological investigation. While this sudden shifting was unfortunate from the point of view of historians dealing with later times, it is an indication of the significance which archaeological work is now assuming.

div.head: Documents
JOURNAL OF MELVILLE COX ROBERTSON
div.p: The soldier who kept the diary here reproduced was the son of James Dowen and Temperance (Gaddy) Robertson. He was born on October 17, 1840, on a farm near Paris , Indiana. The town of Deputy, being nearer the old homestead, is now the post office of the family occupying the Robertson farm.1

Melville C. Robertson attended Asbury College (now DePauw University) and a little later Indiana University where he was a junior in the Law School when he enlisted.2 While a student at Indiana University he was a member of the Athenian Society of which he was chosen president in May, 1862.3 He joined the army in February, 1864, becoming a member of Company E of the Ninety-third Regiment of Indiana volunteers. This Regiment, which formed a part of the Army of Tennessee , was transferred to Memphis in November, 1863. To this place Private Robertson and other new recruits were sent from Indianapolis in the spring of 1863.

The diary and letters reveal the experiences of the young soldier up to the time of his fatal illness. From the Parole Camp at Vicksburg, the released prisoner of war made the trip to St. Louis on the Baltic. While on the vessel, he wrote home on April 20, 1865, stating that he was quite low with typhoid fever. He asked that his father come to St. Louis to see him. In response to this request, the father, and another son, James Dempster Robertson, journeyed to that city, but death came to the son and brother before their arrival.

The first sheets of the diary were sent home before the capture of Private Robertson. That portion of the journal written during captivity was entrusted to a comrade along with other possessions before the homeward journey was begun. When delivered to the family, the diary showed hard usage. The faithful friend of the dead soldier had leaped into
1 Miss Eleanor M. Robertson of Urbana, Illinois, who sent the journal of Melville C. Robertson to the Editor, also constributed copies of the several letters which are printed in conjunction with the diary. Miss Robertson also kindly supplied biographical data of value.
2 Theophilus Wylie, Indiana University (1820-1890), 369, 444.
Melville C. Robertson to his parents, Bloomington, Indiana, May 6, 1862. Cited by Eleanor C. Robertson in biographical data.
the Mississippi when escaping from the burning Sultana causing the leaves of the Journal to become soaked. In order to preserve the record, the brother made a copy which he endorsed: "Melville C. Robertson's Journal, A Faithful Transcript, by J. Demp Robertson." This copy, the Editor has in hand and has used it to check the typed copy supplied by Miss Eleanor M. Robertson.

On a card which he placed in his father's Bible the departing recruit left the following statement:
At home March 21st, 1864
To-day at 2 o'clock P.M. I leave home perhaps forever. If I should return at the end of three years alive I hope to have the proud satisfaction of saying "My country is saved and I have done my duty as one of its citizens." If I fall, let my friends forget my faults and remember me only as a dead soldier of the republic I want no brighter immortality."

It is of interest that after the body of the deceased soldier had been disinterred, brought from St. Louis and buried in the Pisgah Cemetery near Deputy, Indiana, a stone was set up at the grave bearing words from the above: "Remember me only as a dead soldier of the Republic. I want no brighter immortality."

On the day previous to the placing of the card in the Bible, the new recruit wrote, at the beginning of his journal, an acknowledgement of the receipt from his brother of the blank book which he was using:
March 20th, 1864
I remarked carelessly, directing my remarks to my brother Dempster, he who aforetime did instruct youth in a common school in Graham Township, that I would have to have a Blank Book. I was going to the wars for three years, my countenance was lengthened, my voice was doleful; his heart was touched by the funeral solemnity that marked all my actions, and as he had no further immediate use for this "book" he generously gave it to me for which I acknowledge myself very much obliged to him.
Yours Soldierly,
"Kraks"
[THE JOURNAL]
Union Depot Indianapolis Ind
March 30 1864

Have been a month in the United States service without seeing any of the realities of war. Am in the cars now to start for my regiment at Memphis . What will the next three years bring forth? The bell is ringing.
The cars move. Farewell, Indianapolis , farewell Indiana; farewell home, friends, all for the flag.
Centralia Illinois 10 o'clock P M

From Indianapolis to Matoon 150 miles against 4 o'clock P M. There found the people terribly excited over the prospect of an attack upon the town by butternuts to-night From there here on the Illinois Central without any accident All in good Spirits
8 ½ o'clock Thursday March 31

Am at Cairo this morning. Arrived here about daylight. 'Tis as has been represented, a delectable place. Will have to stay here till evening anyhow, and perhaps till to-morrow morning One of our 93rd boys, while gawking around an eating louse a few minutes ago, was accidently shot in the leg. Nothing serious, however, is anticipated from it. A mere flesh wound—have, this morning found myself 325 miles on my road from Indianapolis to Dixie.
Friday morning Apr 1st

Left Cairo this morning at a quarter past three. A rainy, gloomy morning. Thoughts of home and absent friends spring up unbidden. Must crush them out. Prudence tells me so, though they afford me a pleasure all too melancholy A few minutes ago we passed the now historic Island No 10. It is but a small place but even a civilian cannot fail to perceieve the importnce of holding possession of it, if we would command the Mississippi .
Saturday April 2nd

In Memphis at last. Got into camp about 9 o'clock. A M Memphis has been a nice place once and still retains some of its beauties. Our Camp is in one of the nicest places in the neighborhood of the city. Our camps are camps, substantial log or plank cabins with brick chimneys. Soldiering here for three years without a fight would be pleasant, I fancy, I am highly pleased with my company officers My first impressions are that they are gentlemen and I have faith to believe that time will show these impressions to be correct Perhaps my judgment has been biased by the favor they have shown to me a perfect stranger to them.
Sunday April 3rd

Today has been my first Sunday in the "Sunny South" The forepart of the day was splendid—the after part not so much so, for at this writing (4 o'clock P M) it is cloudy and raining Our chaplain, they say, is gone so we have had no religious services in Camp today. This evening I witnessed for the first time the operation of "bucking and gagging" an unruly soldier Life is sweet but it seems to me, shooting would be preferable to me
Monday April 4th

When I started from home I expected to find the weather mild and pleasant in this latitude but I find myself sadly disappointed. Today has been as cold and blustering as we usually see this time of the year
in Indiana Company E is a spunky animal I judge from demonstrations I have witnessed since I came among them One fight since I have been writing They might hold themselves profitably I think Forrest may be in before morning and give them a chance to empty themselves against him He is reported within ten miles of here this evening There has been skirmishing with some loss on our side today. O what a horrid thing is war at the best but this war of brothers what pen can describe its horrors.

quote.p: "The bitter tide of hatred stronger runs and deeper grows
As the pleading voice of nature addeth self-reproach to blows"

div.p: April 5 1864

Tis nearly sundown—one of the most beautiful evenings I ever saw. Yesterday was a time to make one think of a stormy Indiana March day—today would have passed for may in that latitude. "Nary a fight" yet. Forrest didn't come last night and I haven't heard a word said about the apprehended attack to-day As I write they come around for three more men from our company to strengthen the pickets to-night. This may mean something.
April 6th

Nothing of importance to record to-day except the discovery of an old acquaintance in the regiment, Mr Milton Wilson of Scott County I saw him two or three days ago and thought his face looked familiar This evening on Dress Parade I set myself to work to locate him, which I soon succeeded in doing We had a pleasant time to-gether talking of old acquaintances and old times. Weather pleasant to-day, with appearance of rain shortly.
Guard Mounting April 7 1864

Orders came around about midnight last night to each company in the regiment to stack arms in front of their quarters at revielle, and awaith further orders in their quarters with their accouterments on About sun-rise the regiment was ordered out on the "Color line" stacked arms and laid by them till breakfast time when permission was given them to go and eat Troops from front of us have been moving into town this morning As yet I have seen no enemy nor heard anything definite regarding one There is, doubtless a pretty large force in the neighbor-hood somewhere but where it is I cant tell. Some reports place its number at 25,000 Notwithstanding the rumors of the proximity of the enemy I kept my bed till sunrise and then read the paper till our darky blacked my boots for me
Sundown
No rebels yet Nothing said about them One man tied to a tree this evening for being drunk and disorderly. Weather still threatening rain
April 8th

After dark. To-day has been particularly uneventful to me with the exception of the reception by me of two letters—the first I have got
since arriving in Memphis —One from Demp and one from Florence. They were the richest treat I have been admited to since leaving Indianapolis . Company "E" still retains its combativeness—two of its worthy members had four fights this evening about their share I think Two of their battles I witnessed myself I have often heard of men fighting like dogs and then shaking hands in friendship over it afterward but it was never my fortune to see it done till to-day After the second fight these fellows came together in perfect good humor—but it was all "no good" the whisky in them brought them together again in a half an hour
Saturday night April 9th

Today has been very disagreeable, cold, rainy and windy The weather has been just right to make one feel cozy and comfortable in the tent by a rousing fire Nothing of importance to record of camp or rebels today
April 10th '64
A very pleasant day has Sunday the 10th of April been very unlike yesterday; warm and sunshiny No fight in company E to-day, consequently no excitement Today may be set down as dull.
April 11th
Nothing today
April 12th

This evening was kindly invited by Quartermaster Quail to ride down town with him The invitation was accepted with alacrity When I went over to the Adjutants tent to get my pass countersigned I made the acquaintance of Liet Sid Tinker at present acting Ad'jt for the regiment He is an old acquaintance of several of my friends and a school mate of Demp's He went down town with us Is a very pleas-ant fine little fellow I think. Had a better chance of seeing the city than I have had before. Went down as far as Fort Pickering Those black looking fellows that command the town look dangerous
Wednesday night April 13th

To-day have heard that Fort Pillow is in possession of the rebels—will I suppose cut off communication with the North for a day or two at least Received a letter from Cousin Mate to-day She like every one else I have heard from, expresses her surprise that I had patriotism enough to go into the army. Went to prayer meeting to-night. Had a very interesting little time; reminded me of similar gatherings I have attended nearer home.
April 15th
At work to-day writing.
April 17th

To-day, I have spent loafing, smoking, reading, writing and going to church. Heard our Chaplain preach a very good sermon from the words: He that is not for me is against me; he that gathereth not with me scattereth abroad. One of Co "E" men went out and got
his skull peeled Took it very coolly. Didn't seem to like the sewing up part so well.
Monday April 18th

In my juvenile days when paternal thrift and watchfulness was giving me lessons in practical industry after the plough and at the end of the hoe handle, I had pleasant dreams of an Elysium where Idleness was the presiding deity. The dream of bliss however has faded away before an almost entire absence of anything to do in Camp. Time wears away slowly when I have no employment at all. Oh for a little labor with the privilege of choosing my own kind. There was a review of the Memphis militia down town to-day After it was over Gen Hurlbut made a farewell speech to them He leaves here in a day or two to take command at Cairo. Buckland is now cock of the walk here Delayed mail came down to-day and I had the good luck to get nothing where I felt almost confident of two or three letters anyhow. "Sich is life."
Tuesday April 19th
I witnessed something to-day that I never expected.

The diary stops abrutly here. It is probable that some leaves sent home in letters were lost. The following letter will help to fill the gap:
Memphis Tennessee
April 29th 1864
Dear Father,
Orders came to us this evening to draw two days rations and be ready to start on a march at daylight in the morning. The officers and soldiers are directed to leave all extra baggage behind. We are not to leave here permanently—it is to be only a scout of a few days. At least that is the general opinion. There is to be a strong cavalry force to accompany us I think. The movement is probably to be a feint on some point to draw the attention of Forrest while something else is done. Look for stirring news from all quarters within the next six weeks. My opinion is that this is a part of a general movement of all our forces. = I am fat, hearty, all right. I haven't time to write a letter tonight. I will let you hear from me at the earliest moment after I return here—or the first time I have an opportunity of sending a letter if we do not come back soon.
My love to all and every one
Your Son Melville
The next entry undoubtedly belongs to the journal. It was mailed home with a letter and not incorporated in the diary when copied by J. Demp Robertson.
Memphis , Ten. May 29" 1864

Sunday evening about eight o'clock finds me seated for the purpose of noting some of the not very startling occurrences that have
fallen under my observation during the past week, and of whiling away in writing an idle hour. What a vast amount of moralizing may be the result of this "sitting" and what an abundance of sage reflections and trite observations may fall from me before I arise remains yet to be seen—I commence this under circumstances rather unpromising for either speed or excellence in execution. The tent is now momentarily empty as the boys stand in line to answer to their names at roll-call but they will soon be back. If they were all duly sober my task would not be quite so difficult as I apprehend it will be as they are For the truth in regard to their condition is that two or three of them are not "beastly sober." It would be a good thing for our regiment in several respects if we were in a situation requiring more active service than we are engaged in here. In the absence of anything else to do a great many of the boys engage in the pleasant and profitable pastime of getting drunk and raising "old Harry" in the shape of a fight rather more frequently than is amusing to me. When men have plenty of hard work to do in the field they do not have the opportunities for dissipation they have in such a place as this Their habits are better and a better feeling exists among them. This is the testimony of men who are supposed to know and it looks reasonable. I have before remarked the great evils resulting from intemperance in the army and the observations of every day but serve to confirm and strengthen me in the resolution I have made not to be induced by any means to touch intoxicating liquors in any form while in the army. I see here men who were strictly temperate at home forming a habit of tippling which they will one day regret. And this because they have not moral courage to refuse the offered cup. It is no difficult task to live temperately here if men will commence right take the proper stand and there is no great amount of difficulty in adhering to it. And besides this men are better respected and more confidence is reposed in them even by those who make a practice of drinking because they are temperate. I have been faith-fully "tried on" to "take some thing" but have found no difficulty in refusing. And now that it is known that I do not drink although the bottle may be offered me out of courtesy the matter is not pressed and the principle on which I refuse is respected…. But whether it is respected or not, I do refuse, and will continue to refuse and if men do not have enough of the spirit of true manhood about them to regard me with at least as much favor as if I chose to travel the road to ruin with them they shall have the right to their opinions of me and I will consider myself fortunate in avoiding their society.

The events of the past week have not been of a very startling nature nor very many in number at least those that effect me. Last Monday a steamboat collapsed her flues at the landing and killed two or three persons. on Tuesday some guerrillas fired upon our pickets but did no damage farther than to scare them some and on Thursday evening friend Mooney presented me with a four dollar hat which last being an article that I began to stand some what in need of raised rather livelier emotions in my breast than any thing else
that has fallen in my way for some time.

We have had our usual number of rumors of marches through the week but the rumors have not yet moved us from here. To night there seems to be "something in the wind" Pieces of artillery and stray cavalry men are flying past every few minutes some towards town and some out. It is probable there is to be a cavalry raid into the surrounding country somewhere, and that preparations are now being made to start.

Have received no letters from home during the week, the first week I have missed for some time. Got one from the neighborhood though, from Mary Smith. Also received letters from Mate & Mal Gasaway, Magg Payne and one from Miss Ollie Maybury. I received a letter from Benn some time ago in which he told me that Ollie while on a visit to Charlestown requested him to tell me to write to her which I accordingly did and received a prompt answer.
Monday morning May 30" /64

A splendid morning, and by the way all the mornings of the past week have been that, ushering in days that, without the dust which abounds, would make a man with an easy conscience feel "bully" using an elegant but very expressive phrase. They have been neither too cold nor too hot. The dust however is getting to be very unpleasantly thick. We have had no rain for some time and the incessant passing of cavalry camped in front of us, with their horses to the river for water and back, has loosened up a vast amount of it in the road runing past our camp.

My health still continues good, and my relationship with the Sutler's establishment unchanged. To the last I am indebted for the good cigar which now stands out from my mouth an ornamental column to my elegant "phiz." The regiment is still drilling reularly every day, a pastime which I am happy to say I am not yet required to indulge in. A slight change in the order of drill during the week, Brigade Drill on Tuesdays & Thursdays instead of Battalion Drill. It is a Drill I have not yet witnessed as it takes place at the old Fair Grounds about a half mile from our camp …. For this time I stop.
A letter of May 31 fits in well at this juncture. It is followed immediately by the next entry in the journal, that of June 1.

Since dark to night we have received orders to march at five in the morning. We have been busy making the necessary preparations ever since. I now snatch a few moments to drop you a note informing you of the fact.

Where we are going I cannot tell, certain. Reports are that we move towards Corinth. From what I can learn there is a large force going. Convalescents, sick, and baggage are to be left behind. It moved. Convalescents, sick, and baggage are to be left behind. It
may be only a scout of a few days, or it may prove a permanent move and the camp be moved to us. As for myself I am in excellent trim for it and have worked my plans so well that I have no knapsack to carry. I am in with the medical department and have managed to have everything hauled I want to take along. I have no time to write more but will embrace the first opportunity of informing you of my whereabouts and condition.
Wednesday June 1st

The close of my first day march with a musket on my shoulder. At about 10 o'clock this morning we left the city of Memphis on the M & C R R. We came on the cars about twenty three or four miles, passing what once were two or three nice villages, now almost deserted—leaving the cars we marched three or four miles In about fifteen minutes after we took the road for it; it commenced to rain and as all my baggage was in an ambulance I [was] beautifully wet. Stopping in an open field about an hour ago we have prepared for a bivouac It has stopped raining I have taken a supper of "hard tack" and onions which some of the boys foraged on the road and coffee, and feel as well contented with my present situation as I ever did with one in life Much better than I expected I would be I have made arrangements to sleep on the ground under the ambulance with my friend Dickey to whom I am indebted for having my baggage hauled. He is Hospital Steward; is well educated, and is one of Nature's noblemen.
Noon Friday June 3rd

Yesterday we staid all day at the place of our encampment the night before. This morning at 4 o'clock we started out; our brigade in front; our regiment the third from the front, that is of the infantry, there is a large force of cavalry ahead. There is another Brigade of whites and one of negroes along. The whole force is at least between eight and ten thousand We are going in a Southeast direction towards Salem Tennessee . It has rained on us a good deal of the morning but the roads are not very slippery except in some places; mud is ten times more disagreeable than dust. I stand it first rate
Lamar Miss 10 A.M. Sat. June 4th

About 1 o'clock yesterday evening we started on the road again In about an hour it commenced raining and continued to rain on till night My oil blanket protected me for an hour or two after that it came through and I was wet to the skin long before we got here We marched eight miles and came through without stopping a moment. The mud was about shoe mouth deep and I felt like I would be about out if we continued much longer But we had not stopped long before my weariness was all gone. We stopped in an open field on the east side of what was once the village of Lamar. Now there is only two or three buildings inhabited There are several others still standing
The rain was coming down in torrents when we stopped and an immediate rush was made for the old buildings, and the fences around the others for plank and rails to make shelters and for wood A guard had been stationed to protect these but men wet and cold were not to be easily managed. I went to an old house and staid during the night. This mornin at 4 o'clock we started on our way for this place We made an easy march over good roads so far as condition is concerned although they were rather hilly. We made frequent halts from one cause and another, arriving here precisely at twelve a distance of ten or twelve miles Here we have stopped in a nice grove, drawing rations for two days and will remain until to-morrow The boys are "going" for pigs and chickens. Dickey and myself captured and confiscated a chicken which didn't go bad by any means As yet I know nothing of the object or destination of the expedition
Way down in Mississippi Tuesday morning June 7th

Yesterday morning we started from Camp at 4 o'clock In a few minutes it commenced raining and rained on us for about three hours, a part of the time about as hard as it usually rains The roads in consequence became very slippery and bad and the artillery in front got along very slowly over a bad road. We kept on the road until about four in the evening making about fifteen miles. The crackers in our haversacks made our dinners, which we eat when ever we felt like it I was very tired when we got into camp as it was awful walking over the muddy roads. A good wash, supper and breakfast has put me in good order again and I feel as much like the work before me today as any time since I left Memphis Our regiment is in advance today It is probable there will be skirmishing to-day. If there is we will be in it.
Ripley Miss June 8th

We started from camp yesterday morning about 11 o'clock, changeing our course from East to nearly due South We got in here a distance of ten or eleven miles about Sundown. The roads were good and the country more level than it was the day before but the soil the same sandy as before and the timber pine and oak The country was more open and more thickly settled than we have passed through since leaving Salem We were in the advance and on the lookout for rebels but none were seen The citizens here say a small squad of thirty or forty passed through here awhile before we came in They are evidently hovering in our front to Watch and report our progress The town of Ripley is the county seat of Tippah county, and was once a beautiful village Now it wears the same look of desolation that marks all the country we have passed through The court house is burnt and all the places of business deserted, windows broken in and doors bursted open as if they had been pillaged Last night I slept in a building by which we are encamped and which is used for a seminary for young ladies I am informed there is about a hundred in attendance Some of our men were taken to account this morning by Col Poole for pillaging houses One of theme was tied up to a tree
by the thumbs for his fun after the stolen article was returned. We are allowed to take what eatables we must but nothing else.
4 miles south of Ripley Wednesday night June 8th

We started from Ripley about twelve or one o'clock today and got out this far by four. We move very slowly. The enemy this evening are reported in force ahead, with what truth or how far ahead I cannot tell We may have a fight tomorrow I think however he will not make a stand this side of Tupelo if there. To-night promises to be rainy but friend Dickey and myself are pretty well prepared for it We have stretched a tent of our oil blankets cut a lot of walnut bushes, made a bed of them and our woollen blankets and propose to have a good time of it.
Thursday morning June 9th

It is now 9 o'clock and we have not yet moved I slept well and dry although it was raining quite hard when I went to sleep. We are camped in a nice grove from which we miss the pine tree which has been with us for the last few days The timber is gum, oak hickory and walnut For the last few days water has been plenty owing to the quantity of rain that has fallen I think that usually water is scarce. From present indications I think we will move in a few minutes how fast or in what direction remains yet to be seen A thinning out of our train takes place this morning All wagons not absolutely necessary for our use, and all surplus baggage are to be sent back to Memphis this morning Wrote letters home and to Florence this morning and sent them back with the train.
A little later

Still here, have just been up to some prisoners our cavalry captured yesterday—the first I have seen—there are twenty-two or three—two Second Lieutenants among them They are about on an average in appearance with the same number picked at random from our army
Friday morning June 10th

Moved yesterday about Twelve, our regiment in the rear guarding the train. It was very nice with the exception of bringing us so late into Camp We got to camp about eight o'clock, took lodging in a thicket just as it commenced raining. The rain did not last long and I had a pretty good nights rest. We came eight or ten miles through the same kind of country we have been passing through for a day or so. Yesterday evening I passed a little fresh made mound marked "C Rhodes Co B 3rd Iowa Some fond heart will be o'ercast with gloom when the news goes home that an Iowa soldier was shot by a bushwhacker in Miss while riding along with two companions. The report is abroad in Camp this morning that Atlanta has fallen into our hands. It comes from rebels and as it admits reverse to their cause is entitled to some credit. I pray it may be so. For all that we have heard of the world for the last ten days we might about as well be out of it With the exception of this rumor we have heard no news at all since we left Memphis .
Saturday morning June 11th

Yesterday morning I was marching on with a proud army, confident in its strength this morning I am a prisoner and that same army flying in disgrace before the enemy. We marched about twelve miles yesterday and at about three in the afternoon came upon the enemy and had a sharp engagement in which we were repulsed A panic followed, our forces were thrown into the greatest confusion I escaped unhurt with a hole torn in my pants by a ball and one in my shirt by a like missle. Our Adjutant was shot in the early part of the action and died almost immediately. He was a noble and brave man. Lt Col Poole was dangerously wounded and carried from the field near the same time. I could have escaped with the column but chose to remain behind with Dickey, Dr. Sackett and Waits to try to get Col Poole off We were all captured together about six miles from battlefield We have all been detailed by the rebel authorities to take care of the wounded of which there are something over twenty at this place.
Sunday June 12th
Am still here. Adjutant and two of our men who died last night were buried to-day Experienced the kindest treatment from the rebels in charge of us.
Monday June 12th [13th]

This morning helped to consign another federal soldier to his last humble resting place This evening was brought to Brices roads the seat of the late battle and was detailed as nurse in a hospital of Federal-wounded.
Wednesday night June 14th

At the same old place and a horrid one too. Sixty men here suffering with wounds in almost every part of the body. Saw a leg and an arm taken off to-day Hospital visited to-day by several Southern ladies with such delicacies for our wounded as they could raise. God bless them for their kindness to our poor boys True woman is an angel everywhere. Cap McGrayel passed here a prisoner today I fear almost our whole command has been captured.
Thursday June 16th

Still at the battlefield in the Hospital. The wounded are being moved on to Guntown a place on the Ohio & Mobile R. R. from where they are being forwarded to Mobile Ala All of our wounded but about twelve were moved yesterday The few left and three nurses besides myself are here expecting to be moved today. The Dr tells me I will be retained as a nurse. The Surgeon in charge of the Hospital is Dr Mc— of the 3rd Ky In a conversation yesterday with him he told me he was well acquainted with my friend Curran Dé Bruler, and roomed with Jim White while at Medical school in Louisville He says the Chicago Times is considered in the south as sound on the question of "Southern Rights" as any southern paper, better than the Mobile Register. Ladies still keep the Hospital bountifully
supplied with eatables I had quite a chat with one of your ardent but sensible ones on the "vexed questions" by the name of Mr. Tronklin. No proselytes were made by either though the time passed pleasantly. This morning while dressing the wounds of one of the 81st Ill the death struggle came on, and it became my melancholly duty to close the eyes of another Federal soldier

A letter of a comrade gives some details of the battle in which Robertson was taken prisoner. Accompanying this letter was a note sent to the Federal camp by the prisoner. It was written on a small scrap of paper, on the other side of which was the soldier's name and address of his father, J. D. Robertson. The message read: "I am well and well treated but have not opportunity to write. Don't be uneasy about me." The Mooney mentioned had been a student at Indiana University, where he and Robertson became friends. While the letter was written June 30, the writer evidently had no news of the transfer of the prisoners to Mobile as detailed in the Journal on June 18.

I write to you in relation to Mell. C. Robertson. he was captured at the Battle of Brice's Cross Roads on the 10th. I suppose you have heard of the Battle ere this time our forces were defeated. Our Regt (the 93d) was most all captured and Mell was among the captured. Our Capt. McGrayel was captured Liut Mooney was wounded, but made his Escape About half of Co. E. was captured or killed. We heard from the boys that were captured by a flag of truce. they are at Maridean [Meridian], Miss. they are all well and treated well. Mell sent the little note which I enclose to the Co. and it was handed to me to write to you as I was one of his old mess mates. I think you need not be uneasy about him for he says he is well treated. the 93rd now numbers 160 men for Duty I don't know whether we will stay here long or not perhaps we will not. We are now guarding the R. R. The Rebs are reported to be at Corinth we have a large force this time we will make them skedadle this time sure

closer.signed:
H. D. Castetter
Co. E. 93rd Regt Ind.

div.p: Mobile Sunday evening June 18th

On Thursday evening our wounded was moved to Guntown and the most of them put aboard of the cars and started to this place The next day I started as a nurse with the last lot of our wounded and arrived here this morning passing about forty hours on the cars. On arriving here the wounded were all carried to the wash house and
cleaned and arrayed in C S A shirts and drawers before being admitted to the house. I am glad to see them so pleasantly situated to-night But alas they are far from home. My heart sinks within me as I reflect on my own situation, how much worse is theirs. If I could only assure my friends' at home of my safety I would feel so much easier. The consciousness that they are in suspense in regard to my fate makes me uneasy. Oh! the trial.
Mobile Friday evening June 24, 64

In the city of Mobile, a Hospital nurse and a prisoner. One year ago I would have been somewhat startled if I had been assured that this would be my condition now. But stranger things have happened. Well, well, so wags the world, and I am meeting my fate with far more philosophy than I formerly imagined I could bring to my aid for such an occasion as this … While writing the preceeding, the death gasp of a fellow soldier called me away I closed his eyes, he lays in the dead house to-night, tomorrow the enemies of his country will lay him in a nameless grave God preserve me from such a burial. Let me die and be buried at home by friends no matter how humble they may be. Oh let affection's tear water the mound that rises over my lifeless breast.
General Hospital Mobile July 4, 1864

Last Friday we were all removed from the Hospital to which we were first sent to this one a distance of 24 of a mile Our party now numbers twenty nine. 23 wounded 2 Drs and 4 nurses The building we are now in was the old U S Marine Hospital It is a pleasant place. We have the benefit of a strong breeze from the bay nearly all the time during the day "The day we celebrate" is passing away in a manner rather dull to say the least of it. We amuse ourselves in recalling and recounting the manner in which we spent it in other years.
Marine Hospital Mobile July 18th

Two weeks have passed since the Fourth the date of my last entry. Patients and nurses are still here. Our Drs have been sent to Georgia to attend to the sick among our prisoners there They left the 15th One was an old German Ass't Surgeon 2nd N J Cavalry the other Dr Sackett Hospital Stewart of the 93rd, for 8 months acting Ass't Surg. I hated very much to see him leave He is a splendid boy. The most of our patients are fast recovering. In the course of two weeks I think the major part of them will have been sent to camp. Col Poole and some 5 or 6 others are likely to remain some time I think.
Sunday morning July 24, 1864.

Five weeks have passed since we arrived in Mobile, weeks that have not been so long and weary to me as I once imagined prison life would be. If it is supposed we spend all our time in repining over our hard fate the conjecture is slightly wrong. The majority of our patients are now able to be up most of the time and we are inclined to be the most sociable crowd imaginable. The confederacy is most shamefully ridiculed at times I make it my firm purpose and resolve
to live through my captivity and come out of the house of bondage as near new as possible. The weather is remarkably cool to-day indeed we have never suffered any great deal from heat since we have been here. We are expecting every day to be moved from here—at least those of us who are fit for Camp life Our room is beginning to be badly needed.
Monday August 8th

Last Sunday week July 31st 13 of our wounded were discharged from the Hospital and sent off to a prison camp in Georgia . We suppose the other 3 nurses went with them I was left behind with ten men who are not yet able to leave among whom are Col Poole and two Caps of the 95th Ohio of our Brigade, Hanson & Allis. t have been kept quite busy in attending on all these myself but there has been one great advantage attached and that is the increased rapidity with which time seems to pass. Last Friday the 5th our fleet with 3 monitors passed Fort Morgan at the bay of Mobile, with the loss of one monitor sunk A fight with the rebel fleet ensued resulting in the capture of two of the enemy's ships, and the breaching of an-ether. The same day the rebels blew up the works at Fort Powell, and abandoned it. An attack on the city is apprehended soon, in the meantime we are to be shipped to some point up the Alabama out of reach of the "merciless invader" We expected to start yesterday but did not get off and are still here momentarily expecting orders to move.
On Board Ariel August 10th

Day before yesterday evening we embarked at Mobile for Selma. The "good Ariel" is a leaky and rickety old craft of tub-like proportions, in the service of the rebel government. There ar near a hundred prisoners on board all of whom except seven nurses are wounded Many of them are nearly well and will probably be sent at once to prison camps. Surgeon in charge talks of leaving some of the worst wounded at Cahaba 25 miles this side of Selma. Selma is 350 [?] miles from Mobile The Alabama river is decidedly the most crooked stream of any size I ever saw. The country through which we have passed so far is very rough and sparsely settled. I suppose we have come 250 [?] miles and have not seen a single town or village however small. We passed a landing at the base of a high hill at the top of which I was told there was a town. That is the only one I have heard of on the route.
Military Prison Cahaba Ala August 13th

Instead of going on to Selma our whole party stopped at this place, landing Thursday the 11th about noon. More than half was sent at once to prison—the rest to the Hospital here—which is said to be the best in the Confederacy—in my capacity of nurse I accompanied them and staid over night—my services not being required longer, I was yesterday morning with 3 other nurses sent here.
Monday evening Aug 15, 1864

Prison is becoming an old familiar place already. This morning I washed my pants and mended them. This evening I washed myself
and with head carefully combed am arrayed in clean pants and shirt and am feeling as comfortable as could be expected under the circumstances Wrote letters to Father and Callie yesterday and sent them out to-day, the first I have attempted to send since my capture.
Friday evening Aug 19, '64

I write this evening because I have nothing else to do—not be-cause I have anything of importance to record. I have tried life in a good many ways but prison life is rather the most monotonous thing yet. But where there is so many together as there is here it can hardly be dull to most of those confined but to myself it sometimes becomes almost intolerable. There is so little of congeniality of spirit among those with whom I am associated that I often feel myself almost completely alone in the midst of 500 men. But when I feel a strong spirit of dissatisfaction creeping over me, I reflect how much worse my condition might be and soon woo a feeling of resignation to my fate; if I cannot be completely satisfied. As I cannot find kindred spirits here I assimilate myself as nearly as possible to those with whom I am thrown for the time being, in all except their viciousness. I am sensible that the best thing I can do is to make the best of my condition and I am trying to do it. I eat my corn-bread, smoke my pipe and look forward for something better.
Monday evening Aug 22nd

I have my seasons of light and shade here as I have had under more favorable circumstances. Yesterday evening we had a short sermon by a local preacher belonging to our regiment The singing and the voice of the prayer brought forcibly to my mind times agone, when the church bells sounded on my ears sabbath evening The shade fell on my spirit then and I wondered what old friends, with whom I used to visit the house of worship, were doing and thinking of. Whether a thought of me sometimes visited then or not Then came thoughts of home, followed by a flood of pleasant memories of old associations. I would become almost oblivious to all around me and then suddenly awake to a sence of my situation The contrast thus afforded depened the shade till sleep overtook me in melancholy musing. I woke this morning in a fine humor and have so occupied myself as to keep in it all day.
Thursday August 30th

Exceedingly [well] with myself and every body else except the confederacy. Had a splendid bit of watermelon to-day—have had the same thing several times since I have been in here. Would like to see Yankeedom before watermelons and peaches are gone. Strong talk of exchange for a week past. Providence speed it. Yestrday our number was increased to about 700 by 180 or 185 more troubled "Yanks" brought out from Memphis by the everlasting Forrest in his late raid on that place.
Friday Sept 8th '64

When I made my last note I had a faint hope that ere this time I should be in our own line but I am still an inmate of Castle Morgan
The authorities still hold out the hope of exchange to us, but my faith in its taking place anyways soon is not very strong I however think there is still a possibility of it. We have been told all along that it was to an especial exchange we were to look for our liberation If that fails we must wait patiently as we may for a General Exchange. Our number has been swelled by occasional additions to 750 We are getting rather too much crowded for health Ague is becoming quite common and as the Hospital is full a great many sick are left in here all the time. Medicine is also very scarce, and the Drs say, with what truth I cannot tell that it cannot be had. We learned a few days ago by the occupation of Atlanta [not taken until Sept. 20th] by Sherman. This is a sad blow to the Confederates if we may believe them. Their papers have made a point of dilating in unmeasured terms of its importance (Disaffection and desertion of Guards)
Monday Sept 12th, 1864

The inmates of Castle Morgan began this week by numerous sundry effects of some half dozen of their number to demolish one another before breakfast this morning, consequence was 6 of them were tied up by thumbs for an hour or two. Talk of exchange yet, but our faith in it grows less every day. Youthful dreams of pleasure living in a castle dissipated by reality. Present willingness to dismiss my armed retainers and retire to private life. Could I but hear from home and know all were well and doing well I could be more content.
Monday Sep. 19th

A shade of gloom is cast over all this evening by the sudden death of one of our beloved prisoners. Shot by the guards for stopping a moment in the passage from the entrance to the yard His name was Huntington of the 19th Penn Cavalry. Much honor does it do the Confederacy. My hopes of anything like an immediate exchange have all vanquished
Wednesday Sep. 21st
Another man shot by same man—my own narrow escape—locality of the wound.
Thursday Sep. 22nd
Orders read by Adjutant this morning for 51 to be in readiness to leave for Memphis for exchange in the morning. Who go? Death of man shot yesterday.
Friday Sep. 23rd
Departure of men exchanged. Sent letters by them to Demp and Florence
Saturday Sep. 24th
Planting of cannon at door of prison Rumors of fall of Mobile.
Tuesday Oct 4th

Last night or rather this morning at half past lo'clock Hugh Roberts of the 9th Minn died in the bunk I sleep in
Wednesday 5th
This morning early a boat from Selma landed near the prison. More "Yanks" was the cry and we soon learned that 500 or 600 had come off the boat Night will find 14 of them in here.
Monday Oct 10th

Am not well to-day nor haven't been since Wednesday last—was taken with a slight fever of which I have not been entirely clear since—last night and night before was very cold lying on the plank without blankets. I thought the night interminable as I rolled around on the board both fever burnt and cold. Feel better to-day Are 1745 men in here now—very much crowded—rapidly becoming very unhealthy Still keep our spirits up with a hope of exchange this Autumn If not ex-changed this winter God have mercy on us.
Wednesday Oct 12th
Very sick yesterday, better to-day—30 went out for exchange yesterday. 150 or over came in to-day will soon be full I should imagine.
Saturday Oct 15th
Very sick Thursday—better yesterday and convalescent today I think. Addition of about 150 to our number night before last. Over 2,000 in here now.
Wednesday Oct 26th

Since my last entry about 250 have gone out wheather for exchange or some other prison we do not know. My prospect of getting out of here soon looks gloomy. I don't like to give up that that I am to stay here all winter yet. Clothing sent through to us-not issued yet. Mortality becoming fearful—man died last night—3 three or four nights ago and one about a week ago under the bunk I sleep on. My own health as good as usual again with the exception of a bad cold which is getting better.
Tuesday November 8th '64

To-day I suppose is the great day of the year up North [Election day] —down here it is passing pretty much as the rest of them do,—8 years and 4 years ago today The evening of Oct 26th 510 more came in making about 2300. We began to amuse ourselves by conjecturing something of a layer to put on top of us. On the 29th however they took the 510 and 150 or 200 more out. Sent them to Georgia we suppose Stockade has been enlarged in the last two or three weeks so that we are not so much crowded as we were Have been informed there is General Exchange going on Don't know whether to credit it or not Have been unwell for a week past,—have had bad cough with light chills. Took medicine for chills to-day.
December 3rd/ '64
Got out for clothing, got shoes, pants and blouse.
Prison Hospital December 31st/ '64

Came here on the 5th sick—confined to my room 19 days—am quite weak yet, but hope soon to be well. Gave us a turkey dinner
Christmas—thought of my turkey dinner last Christmas and sent gentle thoughts to the friends who were with me then. The last of '64—an eventful year—to me at least what will '65 bring forth? Yill I see home before it ends? Weather raw and cold.
Prison Hospital Jan 7th/ '65

Have about recovered my health—expect to be sent to prison soon On the 1st inst two men bayoneted one dangerously—on the 2nd another slightly—on the third a man shot, died next morning. More talk of exchange—hope there may be something in it.
Castle Morgan Jan 20th 1865

Left the Hospital on the 12th and was remanded to Prison—found it very much crowded—400 men who had been in confinement at Meridean had come in while I was gone—raising the number in here to 2300 I have regained my health—have been gaining flesh fast. Last night at 1 o'clock I awoke and learned that there was to be an attempt made to break prison—time set for half past three. I put on my pants and lay down and fell asleep. I awoke at half past three and found all quiet,—and all's well—had hardly passed the guards before all inside the prison were seized—"fizzle"—after proceedings.
Feb 1st 1865

Pleasant weather with prospect of rain. Have had for a few days past quite severe winter for this latitude Have plenty of blankets to keep warm of nights Talk among rebs of peace—all would be glad to have it on condition of returning to allegiance Seem quite aimable since our little rumpus the other night
February 23rd 1865

A rainy day—warm—no cold weather for some time past—expect the winter of this climate is about over Some strong talk of exchange lately I think probably there is some foundation for it Since my last entry I have made the acquaintance of rheumatism,—was pretty bad off for a few days, but am now about well. One year ago today I enlisted—81/2 months of that time I have been a prisoner. On the 7th I received two letters—one from Demp and the other from Fos & George. The only news I have had from home since my capture.
March 4th 1865

To-day will be remembered in the history of the nation as the day of the Second inauguration of "Old Abe" and in my history as one of the days of the great flood in castle Morgan. The heavy rains of the past two weeks brought the water up so that it came into the prison on the 1st—the evening of the 2nd found all over the outer prison and most of the cook yard.—Yesterday morning (3rd) it was running into the inner prison and before night was over all the ground inside the stockade. Night before last I suppose there was a thousand men in the prison who passed the night on their feet half leg deep in water. Hundreds of rats were driven from their holes and were drowned or killed. They had been working all over the prison and when the
water came in the frames on which the bunks are constructed, settled down and men were up all night propping them to prevent their falling The one I sleep on fortunately settled nearly level so that although we slept but little we were not obliged to get down into the water to work at it. Last night the bunks were all firm and I had a splendid night's rest All day yesterday the men who have been sleeping on the ground were busy fixing up small scaffolds of wood' and boards in the water on which they could make [beds] out of the water Late in the evening a few hundred were taken out and more have gone this morning The rebs tell us it is for exchange
March 5th The water has begun to fall slowly-more men taken out to-day.
Monday March 6th

Water still falling—all prisoners taken out this morning but 526. We will probably go to-morrow, the rebs say on the first boat The boat load that left this morning went down the river report say [s] it goes to the mouth of the Tombigbee and from there to Demopolis Those prisoners who left before went up to Selma
Castle Morgan Monday March 13th

The water out of the prison. I suppose the long talked of ex-change is a fixed fact at last On Saturday & yesterday were all taken out and signed the parole. This morning all the skillets were taken out and our blankets taken away from us. We are now waiting orders to start It is uncertain whether we will go today or not.
Selma March 14th

Yesterday evening about 4 o'clock we went aboard the St Charles at Cahaba and without any regret I soon saw the walls of castle Morgan fading from view in the distance I had been there a prisoner within them seven months and one day In that time I was outside of the Stockade but 4 times till I went out to sign the parole on Saturday We got to Selma about 7 or 8 o'clock and was marched out to the Stockade about 3/4 of a mile from the town This morning were marched to the depot in the rain and stood there an hour or two then came back. Selma is a nice place

During the summer of 1864 and the winter following, the family in Indiana heard nothing directly from Private Robertson. Occasionally a brief letter came from some Union soldier or officer in Mississippi relative to a prospective exchange of prisoners. One of these was from a paroled prisoner, who believed that Comrade Robertson would also be among those at liberty in a short time. He reported that his friend was "in the very best of good health." This was written October 1, 1864. Robertson was not paroled until the ensuing spring. It was almost a year after his capture that he wrote the following letter.

I have the supreme satisfaction this morning of writing you a letter that will not have to be subjected to the curious eyes of rebels ere it is permitted to go to you. I bade farewell to Castle Morgan, Cahaba, and Confederate corn bread last Monday week and reached this place four miles back from the city yesterday evening. Now there is a great deal I could tell you and a great deal I would of perils by land and water, among thieves, false brethren and confederates if I could do it orally instead of by letter. I will therefore let all these things pass for the present and content myself [with] a tale short unvarnished and simple. First then, I have reed one letter only from you and one from Fos. since my capture. They were dated Oct. 30" and reached me the 7" of February. They were promptly answered. Now the first thing you do after reading if you consult my pleasure will be to answer this at considerable length giving me all the items of news that will interest or that concerns me—I am in fine health, weigh 175 or 180 lbs. but am in rather poor trim for walking having bruised my feet considerably by a march of about twenty five miles day before yesterday, the most of it in a heavy rain. We are meeting with the kindest treatment now and will soon recover from all the effects of our trip. The citizens of Vicksburgh by contributions and the Christian commission by its agents are attending to our immediate wants, furnishing us combs, spoons, tobacco, ppies, &. The change from confederate "grub" to Federal rations is as you may suppose rather comferting to the physical man. Our men met us with rations night before last and I drank more real genuine simon pure coffe than I had in eight months before.

When we will leave here is uncertain. We are paroled and I understand are to remain here until rebel prisoners are delivered for us. That may be next week, next month or possibly three or four months It seems to be the general opinion that we will have an opportunity afforded us of going home on furlough after we are exchanged. This is however by no means certain. My regiment I expect is now at Pensacola or Mobile. It passed down the river twelve days ago.

Give my compliments to all my friends and tell them that for a time at least, I have abandoned my old occupation of looking through windows protected from the weather by iron bars. Tell them all to write. I will write to them as I get paper and envelopes which are furnished us by the Christian Commission. My love to Father and Mother. Direct to Co. & Regt. Parole Camp, Vicksburgh

While on the way to St. Louis , as mentioned in the Foreword, this soldier, who survived many months of prison life but who contracted typhoid fever in the Parole Camp at Vicksburg, wrote another letter home on April 20. Two
days later, April 22, 1865, he died in the hospital at Jefferson Barracks, St. Louis .

div.head: Reviews and Notices
A Child's Life of George Washington . By Louise Embree. Illustrations by Clotilda Embree. E. P. Dutton and Company, New York , 1932. Pp. 255, $2.50.
div.p: Louise Embree of Princeton , Indiana, has made the life of Washington intelligible and interesting to children of school age, even those in the lowest grades. It is a very attractive addition to Indiana's contribution to the George Washington Bicentennial. It may seem at times that Miss Embree "talks down" over much to youthful readers. However, the proof of the pudding is in the eating and the book has already proved its popularity with those for whom it was intended. An account of this sort could not be expected to make new contributions to historical knowledge nor to take a critical attitude toward its subject. Miss Embree, however, has made a very comprehensive and well proportioned story of Washington 's crowded life and diverse activities. There is a short bibliography. Numerous allusions show that the writer has kept up to date about information on Washington . Her mention of "Wakefield," the birthplace of George Washington , and other references, would enable well informed readers to date the book, even if the year of publication were omitted.

A word should be said about the silhouette illustrations by Clotilde Embree (Mrs. Claude Douglass Funk) of Princeton, New York City , and now of Indianapolis , varying from little insertions to full-page illustrations. They add greatly to the pleasure of the reader with their spirited presentation of eighteenth century citizens. It is surprising how much dramatic interest is contained in some of the black and white sketches, how much pathos has been put into some, and how much cheerfulness and liveliness into others.

It is to be hoped that many children throughout the country will add to their participation in the Bicenennial activities the reading of this life of the "Father of his Country." They will come from it with a fine appreciation of Washington 's character and services.

div.head: George Washington , Patron of Learning. By Leonard C. Helderman. The Century Company, New York , 1932. Pp. xv + 187, illustrated, $2.50.
div.p: This modest volume is, in the language of the author, "an effort to survey a side of Washington 's career not generally recognized and likely to be overlooked." There is no contention that the leader of the armies during the War of Independence and first President of the United States "was a scholar or even an educator in the fullest sense of the term." Nevertheless, one lays down the book with the feeling that the great Virginian was much interested in education and that his work in promoting the cause was quite important.

This monograph of Dr. Helderman, who is an associate professor of history at Washington and Lee University, contains, besides a history of Washington 's part in the founding of that institution, two chapters (I and II) relative to the project of a National University at the federal capital. The plan to found such a center of learning was one in which Washington was vitally interested. The second of the chapters devoted to this plan is significantly called "The History of an Idea." More than a century rolled by in which period none of the efforts to carry out Washington 's idea came to fruition. The conclusion of the author is that, "The project … Ianguishes to this day and fails to arouse enthuiasm among educators." In regard to the universities found in Washington at the present time, the author writes:
Upon the tapering down of the national university project, certain institutions have been established in the capital city which have aspired to be the heirs of Washington 's idea of a full university. None of these, of course, possess any genetic connection with Geore Washington . The most that is suggested is that by location at the capital, by emphasizing government and diplomacy, and by attracting students from a wide area, they have attempted to set their faces in the direction of his purpose.

Washington was interested in several schools, including the United States Military Academy, Washington College at Chestertown, Maryland , and the Alexandria Academy. He was the real founder of Washington and Lee University which started as Liberty Hall Academy, later became Washington College, and finally was given its present name. The gift which the "Father of his Country" made to this institution
constitutes his "largest investment … for the promotion of learning in the United States ," and it is the only one that lives.

The volume will be appreciated by all who are anxious to know more of Washington . It is well and carefully written. The narrative is easy to follow and the book will furnish both useful information and enjoyment to anyone who chooses to read it. In his Preface, the writer says: "From this study the author rises with the profound conviction that George Washington was more than a solemn mediocrity without intellectual interests or influence." With this conclusion readers are quite sure to agree.

Human Sterilization is the title of a fascinating, scholarly volume by Dr. J. H. Landman of the faculty of the College of the City of New York . The book seems to present a thorough and unbiased treatment of the many phases of the subject. Among the many valuable characters are the following: "The Eugenics Movement"; "The History of Human Sterilization in the United States "; "The Nature of Our Socially Inadequate People"; "Human Sterilization Operations"; "The Ethics of Human Sterilization"; "Whom Shall We Sterilize"; and "Problems in the Administration of the Human Sterilization Laws." The volume contains nearly three hundred pages of reading matter in addition to appendices, bibliography and index. The format of the book is excellent. It is published by The Macmillan Company at a price of $4.00 per copy.

Many students are now engaged in investigations of various phases of church history in the United States . Such students are especially interested in the publication of local church records or histories of local churches. Some years ago (1882), J. C. Tibbetts prepared a History of the Coffee Creek Baptist Association of southern Indiana. Recently a committee, of which Elijah A. Gladden was made chairman, revised this history and brought it down to 1930. The pamphlet has been extended to one hundred ninety-one pages. It includes an account of each of the present, churches in the Association together with biographical sketches of ministers. Several photographs are reproduced and lists of members presented,
while some documents are included, such as the "Constitution" of the Association. The pamphlet, which may be obtained from Elijah A. Gladden of Scottsburg, Indiana, is valuable for several reasons. The publication of such histories ought to be encouraged.

The Mississippi valley Historical Review was founded by the Mississippi valley Historical Association in 1914. The first number of the quarterly appeared in June of that year. The fifteenth volume was completed with the March issue of 1929. At the annual meeting of that year, which was held in Vincennes , the Executive Committee of the Association authorized the preparation and publication of a general index covering the issues of the Review to that date. Miss Louise Rau of the Detroit Public Library was selected to prepare the Index. Her work has been well done. The result is a handy paper-bound volume of one hundred twenty-seven pages, corresponding in its make-up to an issue of the Review. One regrets that the contents of the several volumes of the Proceedings of the Association, which were published some years ago, could not have been indexed with the contents of the Review. If not possible to prepare a combined index, it would seem that a supplementary index might have been added. The Torch Press of Cedar Rapids which regularly publishes the Review, brought out the Index which may be purchased of Mrs. Clarence S. Paine, secretary of the Association, Lincoln, Nebraska , for $5.00.

The Indiana State Teachers College of Terre Haute is preparing to publish within a few months a volume of historical papers which will be dedicated to the late Professor Frank Smith Bogardus. The papers are being prepared and submitted by former students of Prof. Bogardus, who are now engaged in teaching history. Dr. Fred E. Brengle, associate professor of history at the Teachers College, is acting as editor of the volume.

div.head: Comment
div.p: In the good old days, unless, as the debunkers would have it, there were no such times, editorials were widely read. Not only that but they were really worthy of attention. This was because most editorial chairs were filled with men of vigor who were known to the public. In recent times, editorials in daily newspapers are read by few. Even when frank and fearless, as is still sometimes true, readers generally can not associate them with any known man. They lack the flavor given in times past by an outstanding personality, and carry little weight as a rule.

A number of weekly magazines together with a few monthlies furnish readers with editorials that are clear and thought-provoking. They are also read with interest by certain classes in the population, but ignored by a vast portion of the business men of the nation, many of whom take great pride in the fact that they have absolutely nothing to do with magazines that in any degree challenge the accepted notions and shibboleths of the time. This is a bad situation—a very real menace to the future of America.

Periodicals that are published quarterly are not expected to comment on current problems. A curve showing the number of readers of editorials in daily, weekly, monthly and quarterly publications would come dangerously near the zero line for such periodicals as appear only four times in a year. After having encumbered the pages of a few issues of the Indiana Magazine of History with a certain amount of editorial matter, the Editor was about to deny himself the privilege of thus expressing his views when he ran into a subscriber who declared that he always turned first to the pages of Comment. In the course of the last year or two, by keeping an ear close to the ground, the discovery has been made that five others likewise read the editorials. To these faithful and intelligent half dozen readers, greetings! To them these pages are dedicated.

Down with taxes! Down with public expenditures! These are the universal and natural demands of a hard-pressed people.
There, is, however, great danger in; indiscriminate slashing. Taking advantage of the popular mood, elements that desire to carry on various economic activities without restraint or regulation, regardless of the general welfare, may do much harm. Many things necessary to the health and well-being of society under the complex conditions of today can only be accomplished through public agencies. Other essential processes that could be left to individuals or families can be carried on more cheaply and more effectiently by servants of the whole community who are paid out of taxes. It is easy indeed 'to make serious blunders and take backward steps in a period of depression like the present.

Several forms of tangible property are taxed excessively, in reference to values, and also out of proportion relative to various forms of intangible wealth. After a careful study, these evils should be fearlessly remedied. At the same time, it should be remembered that while governments, local, state and national, are taking much in taxes, many other charges that must be regularly paid are excessive and disproportionate. Why should telephone service cost as much as when all prices were at the peak? Why should a public utility company be allowed to collect from any consumer a $3.00 per month service charge for which no electric current is furnished? Why should a number of organizations that few business or professional men can refuse to support continue to collect annual dues which were doubled during the period of high prices? These and many other questions are just as legitimate and natural under present conditions as any that are raised in connection with taxes and public expenditures.

A wise retail merchant knows that he can not sell goods at former prices. The judicious merchant will not therefore stock up very heavily with merchandise which is not quoted at considerably reduced figures by manufacturers or wholesale dealers. He can benefit both himself and his customers by an independent study of the conditions that confront the companies from whom he purchases his stocks. Not all merchants have learned this important lesson. Retail prices have very generally declined somewhat in harmony with the buying power of consumers. On the other hand, many necessary commodities
for which there is a demand are purchased by retail merchants at unchanged prices. In certain instances, there is no help for this, but in a multitude of cases retail merchants can perform a real service for those whom they serve by re-minding wholesale houses or manufacturers that war prices no longer prevail. By doing this often enough and firmly enough, they can aid their communities about as much as if they join the hue and cry for lower taxes or the demand for indiscriminate slashes in public expenditures.

An opportunity to view Congress in action at close range during recent months, while a wide-spread and all too successful effort was being made by various interests to bring the national legislative body into disrepute, leads to the making of certain assertions in the interest of truth and justice. There are very able and very honest men in Congress among each of the four groups—progressive Republicans, progressive Democrats, conservative Republicans, and conservative Democrats. There are perhaps a few cheap men in each group. During the present session, the two houses have been confronted with unusually grave problems and impossible tasks have been demanded of them by powerful elements in the nation. Measures have been urged with tremendous force that were unwise, while wise proposals have been resisted with equal force. In spite of great pressure to compel them to support or to oppose certain policies, many Senators and Representatives have acted with a courage that has not been equaled in the whole history of Congress. Any citizen who has been led to place an unusually low estimate on the American Congress in recent months, who will make an unbiased survey of the actual facts, will be certain to revise his judgment.

div.head: Reprints
div.p: Reprints of any paper published in the Indiana Magazine of History may be obtained by any contributor. Estimates of the cost will be furnished on request and an order placed for as many reprints of any article as may be desired by the author. Requests should be made to the Editor before the issue containing the article of which reprints are desired is published.

div.head: Wanted
div.p: We are sure that some of our readers can aid us to obtain the desired publications listed below. The Library of Indiana University and other libraries in different parts of the country are in need of copies of the issues mentioned in order to complete files. For older and rarer numbers, prices above the regular rates will be paid. Persons possessing any of the de-sired publications, will confer a great favor by writing to the Indiana Magazine of History.

Indiana Magazine of History. We have a serious need for copies of issues from 1905 to 1913—especially for: the four numbers of volume IV (1908); number one of volume VI (1910); the four numbers of volume VII (1911); the four numbers of volume VIII (1912). We will buy also further copies of the following issues: Mar., 1914; Dec., 1921; Mar., 1922; Sept., 1922; Dec., 1922; June, 1923; and Mar., 1926.

Full sets of the Magazine can rarely be supplied to libraries or individuals who may desire to purchase. A complete file from 1920 forward can be supplied at fifty-cents a copy, or two dollars per volume, unbound; from 1914 to 1919, the price is one dollar per copy, or four dollars per volume, except in the case of certain numbers which have become very scarce the price is one dollar and a half per copy, causing the price per volume to vary accordingly; single copies from 1905-1913, when they can be supplied at all, must be priced at a higher figure.

Mr. George S. Cottman, the first editor of the Indiana Magazine of History, who now resides at Madison , Indiana, R. R. 5, has a complete file of the Magazine which he is willing to sell to any library for $200. The first three volumes are bound, but the remaining volumes are unbound. The opportunity to purchase an unbroken file from the beginning is unusual. Anyone desiring to purchase should write to Mr. Cottman, or to the Indiana Magazine of History.
